questions.question: The Alternative Minimum Tax (AMT) is designed to:

options.A: Provide a tax credit for low-income taxpayers
options.B: Ensure taxpayers with substantial income pay a minimum amount of tax
options.C: Replace the regular income tax for all taxpayers
options.D: Reduce taxes for taxpayers with large deductions

questions.explanation: The AMT is a parallel tax system designed to ensure that taxpayers with substantial economic income who benefit from preferential treatment items pay at least a minimum amount of tax. Taxpayers pay the greater of regular tax or AMT.
questions.tip: AMT = backup tax system. Ensures wealthy pay minimum tax despite preferences/deductions.

questions.question: The AMT tax rate for individuals on ordinary income is:

options.B: 21% flat rate

questions.explanation: Individual AMT rates are 26% on the first $220,700 (2024, MFJ) of AMT income above the exemption, and 28% on AMT income above that threshold. These rates apply to ordinary income; capital gains are still taxed at preferential rates.
questions.tip: AMT rates: 26% up to threshold, 28% above. Much lower than top regular rate of 37%.

questions.question: The AMT exemption amount:

options.A: Is the same as the standard deduction
options.B: Reduces AMTI before applying AMT rates
options.C: Is a tax credit against AMT

questions.explanation: The AMT exemption is a deduction that reduces Alternative Minimum Taxable Income (AMTI) before applying AMT rates. It phases out at higher income levels, which can cause the effective AMT rate to exceed 28%.
questions.tip: AMT exemption = deduction from AMTI. Phases out at high income, increasing effective AMT.

questions.question: Alternative Minimum Taxable Income (AMTI) calculation begins with:

options.B: Adjusted gross income

questions.explanation: AMTI calculation starts with regular taxable income. Adjustments and preferences are then added back or subtracted to arrive at AMTI. The AMT exemption is then subtracted to get the AMT base.
questions.tip: AMTI starts with regular taxable income, then add/subtract AMT adjustments and preferences.

questions.question: The Tax Cuts and Jobs Act (TCJA) significantly affected individual AMT by:

options.B: Increasing the AMT exemption and phaseout thresholds
options.D: Making AMT apply to all taxpayers

questions.explanation: TCJA significantly increased the AMT exemption amounts and the income levels at which the exemption phases out. This reduced the number of taxpayers subject to AMT dramatically while keeping the system in place.
questions.tip: TCJA: Higher AMT exemption + higher phaseout = fewer people pay AMT. Still exists though!

questions.question: A taxpayer's total income tax liability is:

options.B: The greater of regular tax or tentative minimum tax
options.D: Average of regular tax and AMT

questions.explanation: The taxpayer pays the greater of regular tax or tentative minimum tax (TMT). If TMT exceeds regular tax, the excess is the AMT, which is added to regular tax. Effectively, taxpayers pay whichever system results in higher tax.
questions.tip: AMT = excess of tentative minimum tax over regular tax. Pay higher of the two systems.

questions.question: For AMT purposes, state and local income taxes paid are:

options.B: Deductible up to $10,000
options.C: Not deductible (added back to taxable income)

questions.explanation: State and local income, sales, and property taxes (SALT) are not deductible for AMT purposes and must be added back to regular taxable income when computing AMTI. This is one of the largest AMT adjustments for many taxpayers.
questions.tip: No SALT deduction for AMT. Major reason people owe AMT (especially in high-tax states).

questions.question: For AMT purposes, mortgage interest is deductible only if the loan was used to:

options.B: Buy, build, or substantially improve a qualified residence

questions.explanation: For AMT, qualified housing interest is limited to acquisition indebtedness (loans to buy, build, or substantially improve a qualified residence). Home equity loan interest not used for home improvements is not deductible for AMT, even if deductible for regular tax.
questions.tip: AMT mortgage interest: Only acquisition debt counts. No HELOC deduction unless for home improvement.

questions.question: For AMT purposes, depreciation on personal property placed in service after 1998 generally:

options.A: Must use straight-line method over longer lives
options.B: Must use 150% declining balance method
options.C: Has no AMT adjustment (same as regular tax)

questions.explanation: For personal property placed in service after 1998, there is generally no AMT depreciation adjustment. The 200% declining balance method used for regular tax also applies for AMT. Older rules required 150% DB for AMT.
questions.tip: Post-1998 personal property: No AMT depreciation adjustment. Real property may have adjustment.

questions.question: The main difference between AMT adjustments and AMT preferences is:

options.A: Adjustments are mandatory; preferences are optional
options.B: Adjustments can increase or decrease AMTI; preferences only increase AMTI
options.C: Adjustments apply to corporations; preferences apply to individuals

questions.explanation: AMT adjustments can be either positive (increasing AMTI) or negative (decreasing AMTI) depending on timing differences. AMT preferences are always positive additions to AMTI—they represent permanent benefits that must be added back.
questions.tip: Adjustments = timing (can go either way). Preferences = permanent addbacks (always positive).

questions.question: Interest on private activity bonds is:

options.A: Taxable for both regular tax and AMT
options.B: Exempt for regular tax but an AMT preference item
options.C: Exempt for both regular tax and AMT
options.D: Taxable for regular tax but exempt for AMT

questions.explanation: Interest on most private activity bonds issued after August 7, 1986 is tax-exempt for regular tax purposes but is an AMT preference item that must be added to AMTI. Some bonds (like 501(c)(3) bonds) are exempt from this preference.
questions.tip: Private activity bond interest: Tax-free for regular tax, but add back for AMT.

questions.question: The AMT exemption phases out at a rate of:

options.A: 25 cents per dollar of excess AMTI
options.B: 50 cents per dollar of excess AMTI
options.C: 75 cents per dollar of excess AMTI
options.D: 100 cents per dollar of excess AMTI

questions.explanation: The AMT exemption phases out at 25 cents for every dollar of AMTI exceeding the threshold. This means the exemption is completely eliminated when AMTI exceeds the threshold by four times the exemption amount.
questions.tip: AMT exemption phaseout = 25% rate. Exemption gone when AMTI exceeds threshold by 4× exemption.

questions.question: The minimum tax credit (MTC) is available when AMT is caused by:

options.B: Timing differences (deferral items)

questions.explanation: The MTC is generated when AMT is paid due to timing differences (like depreciation adjustments). Since these items will reverse in future years, the MTC allows recovery of the AMT when regular tax exceeds TMT. Exclusion preferences do not generate MTC.
questions.tip: MTC = credit for AMT paid on timing items. Recover when regular tax > TMT in future years.

questions.question: For AMT purposes, the standard deduction is:

options.B: Reduced by 50%
options.C: Not allowed (must use AMT exemption instead)

questions.explanation: The standard deduction is not allowed for AMT purposes. Instead, taxpayers receive the AMT exemption. This applies regardless of whether the taxpayer itemizes or takes the standard deduction for regular tax purposes.
questions.tip: No standard deduction for AMT. Use AMT exemption only.

questions.question: For AMT purposes, the medical expense deduction threshold is:

options.B: 10% of AGI

questions.explanation: The medical expense deduction floor is 7.5% of AGI for both regular tax and AMT purposes. This was permanently set by the TCJA. Previously, AMT required 10% floor, creating an adjustment.
questions.tip: Medical expenses: 7.5% floor for both regular and AMT. No adjustment needed now.

questions.question: When an employee exercises an incentive stock option (ISO), for AMT purposes:

options.B: The bargain element is an AMT adjustment

questions.explanation: For regular tax, no income is recognized when exercising an ISO (if holding periods are met). For AMT, the bargain element (FMV minus exercise price) at exercise is an AMT adjustment that increases AMTI. This is a major AMT trigger.
questions.tip: ISO exercise: Tax-free for regular tax, but bargain element is AMT income. Major AMT trap!

questions.question: Long-term capital gains for AMT purposes are taxed at:

options.B: The same preferential rates as regular tax (0%, 15%, or 20%)

questions.explanation: Long-term capital gains and qualified dividends retain their preferential rates (0%, 15%, or 20%) for AMT purposes. Only ordinary income is subject to the 26%/28% AMT rates.
questions.tip: Capital gains keep preferential rates for AMT. Only ordinary income at 26%/28%.

questions.question: A net operating loss for AMT purposes:

options.A: Is calculated the same as regular tax NOL
options.B: Must be separately calculated using AMT rules

questions.explanation: The AMT NOL must be computed separately using AMT income and deduction amounts. It may differ from the regular tax NOL. The AMT NOL can only offset 80% of AMTI (same 80% limitation as regular tax post-TCJA).
questions.tip: Calculate separate AMT NOL using AMT figures. Same 80% limitation applies.

questions.question: Miscellaneous itemized deductions subject to the 2% AGI floor are:

options.B: Not deductible for AMT but deductible for regular tax
options.C: Suspended for both regular tax and AMT through 2025

questions.explanation: TCJA suspended miscellaneous itemized deductions subject to the 2% floor for both regular tax and AMT for tax years 2018-2025. Before TCJA, these were not allowed for AMT, creating an adjustment.
questions.tip: 2% misc deductions: Suspended entirely (2018-2025). No AMT adjustment currently needed.

questions.question: Personal exemptions for AMT purposes are:

options.A: Allowed at the same amount as regular tax
options.B: Not allowed (an AMT preference)
options.D: Suspended through 2025 for both regular tax and AMT

questions.explanation: Personal exemptions were suspended by TCJA for tax years 2018-2025 for both regular tax and AMT. Before TCJA, personal exemptions were not allowed for AMT purposes and were a significant adjustment.
questions.tip: Personal exemptions: Suspended entirely (2018-2025). No longer an AMT issue currently.

questions.question: Passive activity losses for AMT purposes must be:

options.B: Separately calculated using AMT income and deductions

questions.explanation: Passive activity losses must be separately computed for AMT purposes using AMT income and deductions (e.g., AMT depreciation). This can result in different suspended losses for regular tax versus AMT.
questions.tip: Separate PAL calculations for regular tax and AMT. Use respective depreciation, etc.

questions.question: Under current law (post-IRA 2022), the corporate AMT applies to corporations with average annual adjusted financial statement income exceeding:

options.B: $10 million

questions.explanation: The Inflation Reduction Act of 2022 created a new corporate AMT (CAMT) that applies to corporations with average annual adjusted financial statement income exceeding $1 billion. This replaces the old corporate AMT that was repealed by TCJA.
questions.tip: New corporate AMT (2023+): Only for corps with $1B+ book income. 15% rate on AFSI.

questions.question: Charitable contributions for AMT purposes are:

options.B: Deductible, but must be recalculated using AMT figures for percentage limitations
options.D: Subject to a lower percentage limitation

questions.explanation: Charitable contributions are deductible for AMT, but the percentage limitations must be computed using AMTI rather than AGI. This can result in different deductible amounts for regular tax versus AMT, though often the difference is small.
questions.tip: Charity deductible for AMT, but use AMTI (not AGI) for percentage limits.

questions.question: A taxpayer paid $8,000 AMT last year. Of that, $5,000 was due to timing differences (ISO exercise) and $3,000 was due to SALT preference. What is the minimum tax credit (MTC) carryforward?
questions.explanation: The MTC is generated only from AMT attributable to deferral (timing) preferences, not exclusion preferences. The ISO exercise ($5,000) creates MTC because the income will be recognized later. SALT ($3,000) is an exclusion preference generating no MTC.
questions.tip: MTC only from timing items (ISO, depreciation). No MTC from exclusion items (SALT, private activity bond interest).

questions.question: An employee exercises an ISO, paying $10,000 for stock worth $40,000. For AMT purposes, the employee's basis in the stock is:
questions.explanation: For AMT purposes, when the bargain element is included in AMTI at exercise, the AMT basis in the stock is stepped up to FMV ($40,000). For regular tax, basis remains $10,000. This creates a dual basis system until the stock is sold.
questions.tip: ISO stock: Regular basis = exercise price. AMT basis = FMV at exercise. Track both!

questions.question: A single taxpayer has regular taxable income of $100,000, which includes: SALT deduction of $15,000, private activity bond interest of $5,000 (excluded from income), and ISO exercise with $20,000 bargain element. What is AMTI?
questions.explanation: AMTI = Regular TI ($100,000) + SALT addback ($15,000) + Private activity bond interest ($5,000) + ISO bargain element ($20,000) = $140,000. All three items are AMT adjustments/preferences that increase AMTI.
questions.tip: AMTI: Start with TI, add back SALT, private activity interest, ISO bargain element, etc.

questions.question: For 2024, the AMT exemption amount for Married Filing Jointly is approximately:
questions.explanation: For 2024, the AMT exemption for MFJ is approximately $133,300 (indexed for inflation). Single/HOH is approximately $85,700. These amounts are reduced by 25 cents for each dollar of AMTI exceeding the phaseout thresholds.
questions.tip: 2024 AMT exemption: MFJ ~$133K, Single ~$86K. Phaseouts at ~$1.2M MFJ, ~$609K single.

questions.question: The minimum tax credit can be used to reduce:

options.B: Regular tax, but only to the extent it exceeds tentative minimum tax

questions.explanation: The MTC can reduce regular tax liability, but only to the extent that regular tax exceeds the tentative minimum tax for that year. This prevents the credit from creating or increasing an AMT liability in the credit year.
questions.tip: Use MTC when regular tax > TMT. Credit limited to that excess. Prevents AMT from MTC use.

questions.question: The foreign tax credit for AMT purposes is:

options.A: The same as the regular tax FTC
options.B: Separately calculated and may not exceed 90% of AMT before the credit

questions.explanation: The AMT foreign tax credit must be separately computed using AMT taxable income. It is limited to 90% of AMT computed before the FTC, meaning at least 10% of AMT must be paid even with foreign taxes. Regular tax has no such 90% limit.
questions.tip: AMT FTC: Separate calculation, limited to 90% of AMT. Must pay at least 10% of AMT.

questions.question: For real property placed in service after 1998, AMT depreciation is calculated using:

options.B: Straight-line method over 40 years (ADS life)
options.C: The same method as regular tax (straight-line over 27.5 or 39 years)

questions.explanation: For real property placed in service after 1998, there is no AMT depreciation adjustment because regular tax already requires straight-line depreciation. Both regular tax and AMT use 27.5 years (residential) or 39 years (nonresidential).
questions.tip: Post-1998 real property: No AMT adjustment. Both use straight-line over regular lives.

questions.question: Intangible drilling costs (IDC) in excess of the amount that would have been deductible using 10-year amortization are:

options.B: An AMT preference if the excess exceeds 65% of net oil and gas income
options.D: Always an AMT adjustment regardless of amount

questions.explanation: Excess IDC (the difference between current expensing and 10-year amortization) is an AMT preference, but only to the extent it exceeds 65% of net income from oil and gas properties. This is a targeted preference for oil and gas investors.
questions.tip: IDC preference: Excess over 10-year amortization, but only portion exceeding 65% of O&G income.

questions.question: The Corporate Alternative Minimum Tax (CAMT) rate under the Inflation Reduction Act is:
questions.explanation: The CAMT imposed by the Inflation Reduction Act of 2022 is a 15% tax on adjusted financial statement income (AFSI) for corporations with over $1 billion in average AFSI. It is based on book income, not taxable income.
questions.tip: CAMT: 15% on book income for $1B+ corporations. Different from old corporate AMT.

questions.question: If a taxpayer makes a disqualifying disposition of ISO stock in the same year as exercise, for AMT purposes:

options.A: The full bargain element is still an AMT adjustment
options.B: There is no AMT adjustment (treated same as regular tax)
options.C: Only half the bargain element is an adjustment
options.D: The adjustment is spread over two years

questions.explanation: If ISO stock is sold in a disqualifying disposition in the same year as exercise, regular tax and AMT treatment converge—ordinary income is recognized in both systems. No AMT adjustment is needed because there's no timing difference.
questions.tip: Same-year ISO disqualifying disposition: No AMT adjustment. Regular and AMT same.

questions.question: A single taxpayer has AMTI of $700,000. If the AMT exemption is $85,000 and the phaseout threshold is $609,350, what is the reduced exemption?
questions.explanation: Excess AMTI = $700,000 - $609,350 = $90,650. Phaseout = $90,650 × 25% = $22,662.50. Reduced exemption = $85,000 - $22,662 = $62,338. The exemption is reduced but not eliminated.
questions.tip: Phaseout: (AMTI - threshold) × 25% = reduction. Exemption - reduction = usable exemption.

questions.question: The excess of percentage depletion over the adjusted basis of property is:

options.B: Not an AMT adjustment

questions.explanation: Percentage depletion in excess of the adjusted basis of the mineral property is an AMT preference item. This prevents unlimited depletion deductions from creating a permanent tax benefit. Cost depletion is not subject to this preference.
questions.tip: Percentage depletion > adjusted basis = AMT preference. Cost depletion is not a preference.
